best.why: It does the most work. The opening hook is shared with other versions, but B earns its length: it frames the historical argument (press, camera, sampler), lands the thesis ('judgment is the last expensive thing in the room'), and names the movement in a single controlled arc. Every sentence tightens the claim rather than restating it. The rhetoric is confident without being drunk on its own imagery.

worst.why: It's a throat-clear, not an opening. Two lines of shared premise plus a refusal, then nothing. It mistakes brevity for power. A manifesto opening needs to establish stakes and declare a position â€” E only does the second, and even that ('we do not intend to let them') is a negation without content. It tells you what Slopism isn't, never what it is.

must_survive_line: The cost of making has collapsed to zero. The cost of choosing well has not.
